quoteFirst: I sat up, as on the four previous nights, in my favourite bower, and at
quoteLast: these people returned with a large mob of cattle which they had recovered and were bringing home. They were talking excitedly as they approached the pool.
title:
Seventeen trips through Somáliland
A record of exploration & big game shooting, 1885 to 1893
author: Swayne, H. G. C. (Harald G. C.), 1860-1940

quoteFirst: Whilst here I saw two steamers (Lavoisier and Pasha) come up and cruise about Galita together: a merchant ship, and a gun-boat of the Bey's, with which I communicated, asking them to take me to Galita, which I wished to examine personally, as also to speak the steamers, my own crew, with whom I had great trouble, refusing to do so. They declined, when I asked them to take half my crew out, and lend me two men, to which request I also received a negative; so I returned to Tunis, arriving at
quoteLast: on the morning of Tuesday, December 28th. Sir Thomas Reade took all to his house, and made it a home for us. I went on board the French steamer Lavoisier, to thank the captain for his assistance, and also waited on the governor for the same purpose.
title: Narratives of Shipwrecks of the Royal Navy; between 1793 and 1849
author: Gilly, William O. S.

quoteFirst: “Say, boy!” cried Bennie. “This beats sleeping on old hemlock boughs, the way we have to at home, eh, Spider? Remember the way the boughs used to get all full of sticks
quoteLast: last summer?”
title:
Boy Scouts at Crater Lake
A Story of Crater Lake National Park and the High Cascades
author: Eaton, Walter Prichard, 1878-1957

quoteFirst: The next minute the lamp was alight again. The occupants of the room looked at their watches; it was
quoteLast: The next night they sat up again and one of them with a revolver. At about one in the morning this particular individual pointed his revolver at one of the windows.
title:
Indian Ghost Stories
Second Edition
author: Mukerji, S.

quoteLast: , and soon grew to a furious storm. The whole camp helplessly at its mercy. At 8 A.M., took road again. Marched a little beyond Waynesboro', and formed a junction with Army of Potomac. Day pleasant; roads very heavy.
title:
Our campaign around Gettysburg
Being a memorial of what was endured, suffered and accomplished by the Twenty-third regiment (N. Y. S. N. G.) and other regiments associated with them, in their Pennsylvania and Maryland campaign, during the second rebel invasion of the loyal states in June-July, 1863
author: Lockwood, John, 1826?-1901

quoteLast: three clear, sharp cries of an owl, wonderfully well imitated, echoed through the square. Pierrette heard them in her feverish sleep; she jumped up, moist with perspiration, opened her window, saw Brigaut, and flung down a ball of silk, to which he fastened a letter.
title: Pierrette
author: Balzac, Honoré de, 1799-1850; Wormeley, Katharine Prescott, 1830-1908 [Translator]

quoteFirst: It is a peculiar trait of people who go about to amuse themselves, that they are always sure the particular entertainment they have been asked to last is going to "be amusing."  It rarely is different from the others, but these people are convinced, that to stay away would be to miss something.  A weary-looking girl
quoteLast: (at a house-party) when asked why she did not go to bed if she was so tired, answered, "the nights I go to bed early, they always seem to do something jolly, and then I miss it."
title: Worldly Ways & Byways
author: Gregory, Eliot, 1854-1915

quoteFirst: She raised her voice.  "You see, Madame Zattiany, I was running round loose at
quoteLast: when whom should I run into but dear old Uncle Lee.  He looked all shot to pieces when he saw me.  Girls in his day didn't stay out late unless they had a beau.
title: Black Oxen
author: Atherton, Gertrude Franklin Horn, 1857-1948

quoteLast: Oh, the sadness and gloom at our mess that night! Few words were spoken. Some of us hoped against hope. We earnestly cherished the hope that Major Scobell would find some way out of this gorge of death. At 5.30 we were up and ready to march.
title:
South Africa and the Transvaal War, Vol. 6 (of 8)
From the Occupation of Pretoria to Mr. Kruger's Departure from South Africa, with a Summarised Account of the Guerilla War to March 1901
author: Creswicke, Louis

quoteFirst: His troopers emptied their carbines in the direction of the French party as they rode away, but apparently without effect; and the Voltigeurs did not reply, Napoleon having issued orders that there was to be no firing except in case of extreme necessity. The bridges were completed by
quoteLast: on the 24th, and Davout’s corps began to defile across. There was no resistance; the only approach to fighting consisted in the interchange of a few shots between the advanced French troops and the rear-guards of the retreating Russian cavalry regiments.
title: Napoleon's Russian Campaign of 1812
author: Foord, Edward (Edward A.)

quoteFirst: There are dim forms and frosty breaths, and a door which bangs continually, and then the train loads up, the wounded depart, and a heavy smell and an empty pot are all that remain. We clean up the kitchen, and go home
quoteLast: I do the night work alone.
title: My War Experiences in Two Continents
author: Macnaughtan, S. (Sarah), 1864-1916; Salmon, Betty Keays-Young [Editor]

quoteLast: and have ever since been in a whirlpool of work and consequent worry.
title: Frances Mary Buss and her work for education
author: Ridley, Annie E., 1839-1923

quoteFirst: When it began, at length, to abate a little, the four line-of-battle ships and one of the frigates were still in company, and all doing well. The _Mersey_ and the _Emerald_ had steamed into Plymouth, but the five remaining vessels kept in open order throughout that terrible night, wore in succession by night signal at
quoteLast: , made the land at daylight, formed line of battle, came grandly up Channel under sail at the rate of eleven knots an hour, steamed into Portland, and 'took up their anchorage without the loss of a sail, a spar, or a ropeyarn.'"
title:
The Boy's Playbook of Science
Including the Various Manipulations and Arrangements of Chemical and Philosophical Apparatus Required for the Successful Performance of Scientific Experiments in Illustration of the Elementary Branches of Chemistry and Natural Philosophy
author: Pepper, John Henry, 1821-1900

quoteLast: A great and good light extinguished.
title: Lady John Russell: A Memoir with Selections from Her Diaries and Correspondence
author: MacCarthy, Desmond, 1877-1952 [Editor]; Harrison, Frederic, 1831-1923 [Contributor]; McCarthy, Justin, 1830-1912 [Contributor]; Russell, Agatha, lady, 1853- [Editor]

quoteFirst: I was on guard that night, and my post was at the gangway, with instructions to prevent, at all hazards, any attempt of prisoners to go ashore.
quoteLast: a rebel Captain stepped up to me, and addressing me by name, said, "How are you?"
title:

author: Downs, E. C. (Edward C.)

quoteFirst: “I was driving down the beach about a year after she was lost, with my old jagger wagon, and a heavy load on of groceries and stores of one kind or other. It was
quoteLast: , mighty cold, but bright moonlight; and I was coming along by the corner of the fence, you know, just above Jackey’s, when the mare stopped short. Now, she was just the best beast to drive you ever saw.
title:
The Game-Birds of the Coasts and Lakes of the Northern States of America
A full account of the sporting along our sea-shores and inland waters, with a comparison of the merits of breech-loaders and muzzle-loaders

quoteFirst: Two or three times on the way I tried to liven him up, but he took no notice, and we arrived at the station to find the train gone. A belated porter came up and gave me the information that the next train was about midnight, due at Waterloo
quoteLast: , and then my cabman said, “How long’s she ben gone?”
title:
Recollections
The Reminiscences of the Busy Life of One Who Has Played the Varied Parts of Sailor, Author & Lecturer

quoteFirst: My drivers were all picked and excellent fellows. I mounted an old cavalry stager, and we set off
quoteLast: , when I met the guide, who, to my surprise, instead of being an officer or European N.C.O., was a half-caste, and as hopeless an idiot as ever got lost.
title:
The Secrets of a Kuttite
An Authentic Story of Kut, Adventures in Captivity and Stamboul Intrigue
author: Mousley, Edward O. (Edward Opotiki), 1886-
